title: Enabling 6G Performance in the Upper Mid-Band Through Gigantic MIMO
authors:
Emil Bj\"ornson, Ferdi Kara, Nikolaos Kolomvakis, Alva Kosasih, Parisa
  Ramezani, Murat Babek Salman
abstract:
The initial 6G networks will likely operate in the upper mid-band (7-24 GHz),
which has decent propagation conditions but underwhelming new spectrum
availability. In this paper, we explore whether we can anyway reach the
ambitious 6G performance goals by evolving the multiple-input multiple-output
(MIMO) technology from being massive to gigantic. We describe how many antennas
are needed and can realistically be deployed, and what the peak user rate and
degrees-of-freedom (DOF) can become. We further suggest a new deployment
strategy that enables the utilization of radiative near-field effects in these
bands for precise beamfocusing, localization, and sensing from a single base
station site. We also identify five open research challenges that must be
overcome to efficiently use gigantic MIMO dimensions in 6G from hardware, cost,
and algorithmic perspectives.
subjects: Electrical Engineering and Systems Science/Signal Processing
